Or a "Snuggler" which is basically hot cocoa and peppermint schnapps (very good festive on a cold SF night). There was no spiked egg nog though so I was a bit sad. I contemplated whether I was asking for too much ... I think I was.

Overall I am a fan.
author: Greg G.

description:
My buddy Chris brought me out to this joint last week to show me some of the rad Mission bars I had been missing out on.  This place did not disappoint.

Awesome local beer selection, paired with some shuffleboard makes me super amped to come back here.  Plus they do a shot and a beer combo (on Mondays I think but I could be wrong).  Anyway, I totally dig it.  If you wanna go, let me know.  I'm signed up.
author: Nicholas N.

description: It was awesome on an empty thursday night. Pints, neon lights, Indiana Jones pinball (!)
author: Emily D.

description:
The dyke behind the counter was awesome..strong drinks and a friendly attitude. SUCH a rarity in the "oh-so-cool-hipsterville"

CLEAN place, also rare in the Mission.

Great drinks, good drink specials, huge variety, cool people who actually converse with strangers!

Would have given this place 5 stars, but it's stuffy inside, they need to invest in ceiling fans or some sort of cooling system.
author: Ted K.

description:
Docs Clock, yet another amusing and fun Mission bar. Not quite a dive, but it could be if they went more that direction. 

Impressive hand made bloody marys were really good. After 2 of them I was feeling great. The bathrooms are a bit weird, but hey, it's a bar in the Mission, not some fancy place in SoMa.

They have a great selection of beers and alcohol, and they are priced fairly cheaply when you look at the generous pours. I mean the bloody marys were $5/each, so after dropping a mear $15 I was a happy camper.

Not much to look at, not a lot of art and only 1 partially working TV. But they do have a shuffle board in the back along with a few old pinballs machines.

Overall I'm a fan and would totally wonder/stagger back in there again!
author: Erik B.

description: Wow, used to love this place, haven't been there for a long time and won't be going back.  Met my husband there years ago, went there with a group for pre dinner drinks, the bartender is condescending and treated everyone in our group with contempt.  Bartender had the nerve to say to my husband in a very non funny sarcastic way (believe me I know sarcasm, its the only sense of humor we have where we come from!) 'welcome to the mission', we've lived in this area for years, she told another friend to 'back the f**k off' when he approached the bar to order a drink.  Really?? You have a job???? Maybe you think its 'cool' to act nasty, you were in diapers when we started coming to this bar.  You're attitude won't get you very far in life and maybe you should consider a career where you don 't have to have human interaction.
author: bealeasa N.

description:
Doc's clock is located in hipster-central on Mission, but despite providing its clients with the standard swill beer and tatted bar tenders it avoids many of the otherwise negative stereotypes of Mission hipster bars. I like that.

To the point, there is an awesome, ***** (5 star) shuffle board in the back. It truly makes a night. Amen for shuffle board.

They do offer $2 Oly in the can here, which, for a guy who went to school in Montana, is like coming home. Draft Pabst is $2.50, and you can't beat that. The juke box is great, but it's a little too loud in here to actually hear the music on a Saturday night.
author: Wes T.

description:
Ten years ago when I was working in the Mission I had some friends who would go to Doc's Clock.  I guess you could call them hipsters.  They listened to Modest Mouse and the boys panted their nails and wore thrift store threads.  

This place was in the news over and over again.  I would constantly hear stories about vioence in the bar or right in front of it.  Then I would hear even more stories.  Jesus Christ.  People were calling for the bar to be closed due to violence.

However my friends told me how cool it was so I went in there.  A bunch of ugly old drunks were in there.  What the hell.  This place isn't cool, it's lame.  I am not going to waste even 5 minutes in this joint.  I walked by tons of times and looked inside and it always looked really lame.

I am not going to risk my life for a drink.  Maybe it is safer nowadays but I have heard too many stories about the violence that surrounds this bar so screw it.
author: Cynthia B.

description: Great drink prices, shuffle board, connect four,this place is the shit
author: Holly G.

description: This was our second stop for our Mission Bar crawl on Saturday night (after dinner and margs at Velvet Cantina down the street) and this place has something for everyone!  At 9pm, it wasn't too crowded and we staked out the back area, setting up Jenga and Connect Four.  Our group (mostly non-Missionites) made new friends playing (aka getting dominated) shuffleboard and overall a fun time was to be had.  Drinks are reasonably priced and the kitchy decor along the wall was cute.  The quintessential neighborhood dive bar...though I never did figure out what that smell upon entering was :-/
author: Mengo Z.

description:
Stiff, cheap, quick, cash only.
Best Jukebox in town.


My favorite neighborhood dive bar, hands down!


B Movies projected on the wall, board games, shuffleboard, and just all around no frills loveliness.
author: Chanel P.

description: Doc's is my favorite bar in the area! It's spacious and cozy, great service, a great rock jukebox - no internet jukebox bs here - and shuffleboard. It's also dog-friendly complete with dog treats and water bowls. They have charity events as well for all sorts of causes.
author: Kate R.

description:
Aside from the two times I've been here and someone (who under the age of 14 even does this?) let off stink bombs, I enjoy Doc's Clock.

First of all they serve Olympia beer - that is wonderful fun. And it's like $2 or something super cheap. They also have fun games and the crowd is great. A hipster crowd but older, legit hipsters. Good times.
author: C P.

description:
Probably my favorite dive bar.  Where else will the bartender play Scrabble with you while you drink an icy cold beer?

This place has the perfect combo of grimy bar + cool patrons + great, cheap drinks + BOARD GAMES!!  

Nerd alert, but I love 'em and a Ms. Pacman arcade?  Swoon.
author: Christina H.

description:
Nice little dive bar. 
I came here right before Halloween and the place was decorated with freaky, mutilated barbie dolles. It was actually pretty cool!
Beer selection is nice, definitely come during happy hour.
author: Sam C.

description:
I really love this place. The atmosphere is chill, friendly, yet just crowded enough that it feels fun, the staff are great, and there are interesting board games and shuffleboard in the back. There are both cheap and non-cheap beer options available, and you never have to wait long for service.

They're quite dog-friendly, which can be a positive or a negative depending on personal preference.

It's always a reliable good divey experience that's great to start off or end a night.

On the negative side, they do run out of beers occasionally, which is annoying.
author: Ned D.

description: I have only been here twice, and it is a nice little neighborhood bar, at least early on a Friday.  They are cash only, and make a decently strong drink.  The bar comes equipped with shuffleboard, so be prepared to play.  The bar is pretty dark, and has never been packed that I have seen, but like I said, I have only been twice, and both times were early on a Friday.  Nice place to stop after work if you are in the area!!!
author: Dick S.

description:
Came here Saturday afternoon with a buddy of mine. There was no one inside the bar except us and the bartender. Yikes. 

C'mon people, $2 PBR's! 

Hello? Where are all the Hipsters? Donde estas en la Mission?
I'm surprised they aren't drinking this place up.
author: Zam M.

description:
Yea for incredibly efficient, tolerant, and forceful-when-needed bartenders.  Doc's Clock has at least one of them, and she's worth probably more than she makes.

Yea for cute greyhounds that put up with annoying people who patronize Mission bars and just want to pet greyhounds when said perpetually sad-looking dogs are just trying to rest.  Double yea for said cute greyhounds that occasionally jump and rest their forepaws on the edge of the bar.

Boo for patrons of Doc's Clock.  Most of you suck.  Yes, I'm talking about you.  And you.  And you too; don't think I didn't see you trying to dance on the bar.  Yes, you were drunk, but this doesn't give you the right to almost ruin the efficient bartender's night.

Sometimes, I hate the Mission.
author: John S.

description:
This place has the three P's: pinball (the first time I was there, it was one of my favorite tables, The Simpsons; the second time, it was Indiana Jones), punk music (that juke box has some amazing music on it,) and Pac Man... Ms. Pac Man, to be more specific, which is WAY better than the original. My first childhood arcade game was the Ms. Pac Man table top arcade machine, and they have that here.

I guess they have a fourth P... Pabst... but I actually HAVE taste in beer so I'm not counting it :D

I've been here a couple of times with friends, and I have to say this is probably my favorite bar in the Mission... and it's probably my favorite bar in the City overall. The place is fucking cool. The bartenders aren't pretentious, they have games including a shuffleboard that is rarely not used, and on some nights, they project B movies on the wall near the bathroom. Of course you can't hear anything when the bar is crowded, but whatever... it's not like it's the main reason why people come to this bar.

There's only a couple of problems I have with this place... the bathrooms could be way better, and if someone is using the Ms. Pac Man game as a table, you're probably not going to get to play... unless you have a nice group of people sitting at the table. Other than that, this place is great.

If I was hanging out in the Mission with friends and we wanted to go to a bar, I'm totally suggesting this place. Their prices for drinks are really cheap compared to most bars in the City that charge way too much, the atmosphere is great for groups, there's entertainment, they make Hot Toddies, and even when it gets busy, it's not all that bad. I feel sorry for the person who can't have fun at this bar... and this is coming from a guy who doesn't like too many bars, especially crowded messes like the Beauty Bar.
author: Chris S.

description: When traveling, I love to pull a stool up to the bar and talk to the bartender about the prices and the beers on tap. Not only did these stools swirl, but also they had a great late night happy hour that included cheap well drinks and $2 PBRs. I liked it and as I am trying to be a local in San Francisco... I would like to be future regular.
author: Kylie D.

description:
Solid dive bar usually filled with friendly people. Not achingly hipster and 
enough room so you don't feel crowded even on a Friday night. 

The free games give it a nice vibe and the bartenders are extremely friendly and go the extra mile with their service.
author: Ali B.

description:
Shuffle board! Shuffle board! Shuffle board!

A full size table too. This is hard to find in SF so this place is definitely a favorite.

It's one of those bars that I prefer on a mellow night or afternoon when it's not super crowded, but then again what bar isn't better when it's not crowded?
author: Jackie G.

description:
I love you, Doc's Clock. You are really close to my BART stop, your pours are legendary, and your bartendresses are great at both putting up with asshats (like the juggalo down below who slams "hipsters" in the same bit where he bemoans the lack of "beautiful people") and soothing ladies, like me, who often have to put up with them.

I love a bar with games, dogs, movies, and booths - you have them all. Thank you for being awesome while many other Mission bars near the 24th St stretch just ooze "too cool for school" bravada and reek of STDs.
author: Jess F.

description:
Good dive bar that I should go to more often.

It is pretty cheap.  That is good!

It has many references to Milwaukee, where I am from - so that is also awesome!

Board games and table shuffleboard type game... awesome!

When you walk in you don't feel like you are in the mission anymore - you feel like you have been transported to a dive bar in a po-dunk backwoods town.

I like!
author: Kristina K.

description: Cheap drinks, bartender was fantastic. A bit of an adventure, but we loved it!
author: Matt N.

description:
What can I say???????? Doc's Clock is a Rock around the clock!!!! came here Monday July 25th after dinner. I went with Couchsurfers and was surprise to have shuffle game and 3 video games in the one machine. a very rare machine to have 3 in 1. stayed until 11:00pm playing galaga like crazy because I was kicking ass on the galaga. Yes,the bartender dose goes an extra mile they are very friendly as well as the hipster are friendly too.

4 star for this place

1. Friendliness of Staff
2. Free game of Shuffle
3. 3 video games in one machine Galaga, Ms Pac Man and one more cannot remember the name.
4. the price is right on the drinks.

I take away the star did not like the restroom it had orange light kinda hard to see when you walk into the restroom I though the restroom was Okay. 

Highly recommend if anyone loves to play shuffle board.
author: Mat Z.

description:
Wandered over to Doc's Clock after an meal at Foreign Cinema. Definitely impressed -- as far as dive bars go. Even more impressed that they offer Fernet. No dive bar (and barely any normal bar) in Minneapolis offers this fine Italian digestif. 

How I missed the board games and shufflepuck game, I'll never know. Probably because I was busy kicking ass in a beer chugging game.
author: sarah p.

description: good standard dark/loud dive bar, close to 24th & mish, and they have shuffleboard.
author: Sonya Z.

description:
It's located close to a couple non-descript Latin storefronts, and you'd almost miss it if it weren't for the achingly kitsch facade that immediately gives this place its charm. It's not a dive bar; don't let these hollow hipsters fool you. But it is no frills, with daily drink specials and bartenders who call you hun and ones who could give two shits if you were alive or dead. Don't you worry though; each one has a hand of stone. 

The bar itself is a hodgepodge of various libations from seemingly around the globe, with something called "Unicorn piss", a light yellow concoction in a bottle shaped like a horse put out to pasture going for $10,000 a pop. Water is self serve, bathrooms are moderately clean though don't think you will do your disco drugs in there. There's consistently a squirrely traffic of hipsters brimming with PBR coming in and out.

Now my girlfriend and I usually go to Doc's to drink the 5$ Chimayo tequila on hand and drunkenly grope each other in the leather padded booths in the back. If you're adventurerous you can get away with more. The jukebox will only play dirty music from a bygone-era, and the shuffleboard sometimes leaves some patrons in a frothy competitive frenzy. I haven't randomly talked to many people there, which is odd, as most people in San Fran will give you their life story if you happen to make half-lidded eye contact with them. Nonetheless If you are in the mood for a cheap, stiff drink that will leave you feeling fucked, then this is the place.
author: Charles S.

description:
How is it that I have not yet written a review of Doc's?
Stashed inside an old theatre, lights and all?  Awesome.  Cans of Olympia or shots of cheap whiskey?  AND shuffleboard.  I've spent the end of many a good night at Doc's.
author: Eric S.

description:
Four of us went here last Friday night in search of shuffleboard.  We were so happy to find it - and it's free!
The bartender could have been a little more friendly but the happy hour prices until 9 pm were cheap!  They were showing old movies on the back wall and have some vintage arcade games at the back tables.  Had so much fun playing Miss Pac Man.
There was kind of a foul smell coming from the bathroom once the place warmed up.  Not sure what that was about.  Just don't sit too near the back.
It was freezing cold when we got there so if you are going early in the winter dress warmly.
author: Janz P.

description:
Pac Man! na na na na na na Pac Man!

The arcade game makes my inner and outter geek so incredibly happy. Strong pours, good beers on tap, friendly patrons. One of my favorite spots!
author: Allegra F.

description:
I love bars like Doc's Clock. Old, worn in, lived in feeling... it feels like a diner from the 50s. Lots of neon signage and Christmas lights with tiled floors and old lighted beer signs (think 1970s Miller ads). Good stuff.

Cash only (which seems to be a trend with these older bars in SF) but since the Ketel One & sodas were only 5 a pop, I was fine with that.

Great juke (Dead Kennedys, M. Ward, Otis Redding, Sleater Kinney) and a really long functioning shuffleboard table (puts the one at 9LB to shame!) make this a great spot in the mission for a super laid back evening. Lots of board games if that's your thing and a great vibe make this a no brainer when I'm in search of low key drinks in the Mission.
author: Katie A.

description: I dunno about this. I think this is where all the bitter, aging hipsters accidentally on purpose wind up after a long night. I honestly can't think of a time I've come here and NOT had someone say something unnecessarily rude to me while falling into a cheap can of PBR. Once, some guy (who was coincidentally pretty fug) tricked me into playing "guess my age" and then told me I looked 40 and haggard while he pinched my ass. Um, please read the sign, shut your whore mouth, and get your paws off my Phillip Lim. If you need me, I'll be in the back playing shuffleboard while looking youthful and expensive. Thanks.
author: Rebecca P.

description: I went here sober last Sat night and asked the bar tender for the Sierra on tap. The bar tender said, "Do you want the Pale Ale or the Red?" I responded with "I want the Sierra on tap." She gives me a can of Pale Ale. I have never had Pale Ale in a can before, so feeling like an ass if I said anything, I decided to try it. It was awful. I handed it back to her and said I wanted the Sierra on tap, not in a can. She said, "You need to specify!" I responded with "I did specify" and she just ignored me. I said Can I get the Sierra on tap then, because this is garbage, and she said okay and rolled her eyes at me. Came back saying that the tap was warm. So, all that basically came down to her not giving me the tap beer, because it was warm and blaming me on not "specifying." What happened to customer service? This place is a dive and that lady bartender was not nice.
author: Lisa K.

description: Shuffle puck!  Too drunk to deal with anything else, but they had real shuffle puck.  Minus a few stars for the not-nice bartender, but plus one million stars for shuffle puck.
author: Kim K.

description:
Growing up, I had one of those healthy moms. You know the type -- gives carob instead of chocolate, serves rice cakes as snacks and requires 100% fruit juice instead of things like Kool-Aid. So it's no surprise that the first time I had Sunny D was an adult in this delicious concoction they serve at Doc's Clock called Trailer Park Punch. Now, I am not one to generally like fruity drinks, but this stuff is pretty freakin additively good and chock full of Sunny D goodness. 

Other than that, drinks here are pretty cheap and the crowd is not too annoying. You can actually carry on a conversation in here on a Saturday night. 

Plus, as an added bonus, once a month they have a happy hour to benefit animal rescues. Any place that's down with helping animals is all right in my book.
author: Rebecca H.

description: Best bar on Mission Street. Generous happy hour until 9 every night. Awesome Sunday brunch. Benefits for dog rescue places. Just don't order a Mojito!
author: Ethan J.

description: A respectable little dive - drinks at decent prices (and especially cheap beers), dimly lit, some games for your entertainment, and usually a good crowd.  Remember that it's cash only, and it can get packed around happy hour.  But even when it's busy, the bartenders are still attentive and quick to get your drinks.  Close walk to Bart, and a good halfway point between bars near 24th and bars near 16th.  Woooo Doc's.
author: Jenna C.

description:
This is one of my favorite bars in San Francisco.  Board games.  Dice.  Cheap drinks.  I would frequent this place all the time when I lived in the Bay Area...and it was only a few blocks from one of my buddy's house.  I now live in Brooklyn, but I still do think about Doc's quite a lot.

They also have a pretty good selection of hard liquor here.  On one particular evening, I was feeling particularly daring.  I asked the bartender to give me the WORST shot of liquor at Doc's Clocks.  Yes.  I asked that.  The barkeep promptly searched in the abyss of a cabinet behind the bar.  He pulled out some sort of Indian liquor...and then he warned me.  My friend and I took the shot.  And...HOLY SHIT it was awful.  But that's what I ordered.  haha.
author: Victor S.

description: I love coming here. They have great drinks for cheap. The happy hour is pretty good and the bartenders are very charismatic. My friend even got her iPhone recharged when the bartender offered to charge it for her while they made her a "trailer trash". So nice! The shuffle board in the back is where you want to be once you get a few drinks in you. Oh, and it's a green bar!
author: Carlos C.

description: It is smaller than I thought it would be from the outside. I came in with a bunch of plastered out-of-towners who couldn't go more than a few feet without another beer. It was that kind of night. The bartender was surprisingly pleasant given our sloppy state.
author: Jordan P.

description:
Had a great time this past Saturday when trying to get out there and meet new people. Played a bit of shuffleboard (go figure - I'm not so bad!). A little chit. A little chat. And generally a good time in a relaxed dive.

Having said all this, I didn't get the "chatty bartender". Maybe his night off. I got the grumpy guy that hates his life. Oh well, the other stuff made up for it and hopefully "chatty" will be on the Clock next time.
author: Jennifer W.

description: the best goddamn bartenders in the whole city. a phenomenal dive during the week and early weekends. and ever reliable cheap drinks and pups to pet. during the winter months, they have plenty of strong hot drinks to keep you warm and buzzin.
author: Megan L.

description:
People of all genders, sexualities, colors, ages are warmly welcomed here.
The drinks are decently priced, well made, people actually interact with people they don't know here and there's no attitude. And, once a month (or more?) they do a benefit for wonder dog rescue, family dog rescue, and other dog rescues (you can bring your well behaved pup here and there's a bed and a bowl of water for it even).....And, you can find parking nearby, or easily walk here from other bars or BART.

For those of you that don't understand tip etiquette...here's a tip...10% is insulting...it is saying the service was less than adequate. 20-25%, particularly in SF where the cost of living is high and bartenders make most of their money by tips is a good tip. (Or just think $2 a drink...If it's a simple squirt of soda, $1 is good, because it still takes the same amount of energy and time to squirt the soda button as it does to pour from tap....but don't stiff them just because you aren't drinking a beverage with alcohol! They are still working for you!) If you're too broke to tip your bartender, then you can't afford to go to a bar, and need to stay home and drink. Hell, I was tipping $1 a drink in 1989...drink prices have gone up...shouldn't their tips?! If you would like more solid advice on tipping...here's a link http://www.tripadvisor.co.uk/Travel-g191-s606/United-States:Tipping.And.Etiquette.html ... If you don't care, then don't be surprised if the bartender calls you a douchebag, or starts to ignore you...you made your bed. For the most part, I'm treated extremely well by bartenders, because I'm not cheap, and I don't treat them with disrespect. Funny how that works  And before you get huffy about taking to long...stop...look...is there just one bartender, and a whole long bar, with a lot of people? Well don't punish them for that!

End of tipping rant...
Doc's is one of the few places that still has that good, down home Mission feeling that most bars have lost to douchebags...Anyone I've sent here...all different types of cool people, have appreciated that...And there are plenty of good Mexican food, cheesesteaks, and street bacon dogs around!
author: Nick M.

description: Doc's Clock is a default Mission spot.  It's large enough to meet friends and have a decent shot at a table.  Other than that, it's a solid Mission bar.
author: Bill H.

description:
Great dive bar.

Simple yet serves up some good times for all.  We walked over after a night at the Foreign Cinema.  They had quite a collection of tequila.  A jukebox and a chatty bartender. Everyone one wants for our fav dive bar.
author: Rebecca Y.

description:
I dig this place - I don't know about it being a hipster bar (aren't there hipsters at pretty much every cheap bar in the Mission?), but they have a great happy hour that goes until 9, so it's my favorite place for a post-6:30-bikram-yoga-class drink.  Bartender is never overly friendly, but shes fast and pleasant and I don't expect her to be mz. chatty w. the guy ordering cheap drinks.  The 50 cent pretzels are stale, big surprise!

It's definitely picked up in business since I started going there a year ago...one friday night I even passed because there were too many folks there.  I wouldn't spend my whole night here, but for a few drinks it always hits the spot.
author: Tmon B.

description:
In a wasteland of bars that I would rather blow up, and get incarcerated for the act, than actually step foot in this is actually one I would take the rap for if they blew up some of their neighbors. 

I haven't met anyone who said "Bro" here. I haven't seen the place infested with people who will mock me because I do not own skinny jeans, footless tights, ironic tees or chucks. I have not overpaid for a weak drink and have not had service that was inattentive despite the fact that you probably get into the triple digits counting your steps from one end of this bar to the other. 

All of that is great, really, but what about this place makes my heart melt?? They have board games, and tables to play them on. Lots and lots of board games. Board games that I can play while drinking since I am no longer allowed do this in my own home because the wicked witch of the west, who has not been laid, well, probably ever, lives downstairs and calls the cops if I sneeze past 10PM. Oh, and they have shuffleboard, and my place just wouldn't be large enough for that anyhow! 

Isn't it ironic that at this bar I actually do not have to watch the clocks like I do at home?? I guess that irony replaces the hole in my wardrobe where the ironic tees are supposed to go. Thanks Doc!!
author: Drue C.

description: This is one of the worst bars I have ever been to.  The beer selection is small, the seating is uncomfortable and the service is awful.  I've heard of being kicked out for drinking too much, but I was asked to leave on a dead Tuesday night because I wasn't drinking enough.  Seriously, what the Hell?
author: Brandon F.

description:
Woot toot toot. I need to find more places that has IPA on tap. This place will defiantly get my patronage again. Out of all the dives I've been to, all the clubs, and hole-in-the-walls, this place not only had great beer but they have shuffleboard.

The location is great, spacious and plenty of places to stand or sit. The bar tender was cool and I liked how the bathroom was actually clean for it being a bar. Ladies, you'll have no fear of sitting down at this joint.

All in all its a great place for great beer and great times.
author: Wayne W.

description:
OK, so I'm trying to stick with the Senryu review thing and so I'll say: 

drunk on Wed-nes-day 
the burritos across the street sound good 
Connect-4 tiles MIA cry 

eh, it's not working for me. So, instead I'll quote the second best famous person at making the blazer with pushed up sleeves over t-shirt look work for him (after Miami Vice era Don Johnson), the Chicken Lady's cool older brother; Rod Stewart. 

"God I was glad I found her 
And if they had the words I could tell to you 
to help you on the way down the road 
I couldn't quote you no Dickens, Shelley or Keats 
'cause it's all been said before 
Make the best out of the bad just laugh it off 
You didn't have to come here anyway 
So remember, every picture tells a story don't it" 

Let me put a little oomph of emphasis on that second to last line. 

So come on down and sift through the board game rubble with me and marvel at the stalwart lack of concession to hipness that the jukebox has going for it. 

Roll your eyes as I overreact to my cocktail straw being repeatedly lost in my drink because they ran out of cocktail straws and have been reduced to cutting regular straws in half (which just does not work for shit). 

Absorb the unspoken wisdom of their bartenders as they apply Buddha like aplomb to the clientele who refuse to acknowledge Rod's penultimate line of lyrics from "Every Picture tells a Story".
author: Milk N.

description:
It was love at first sight of the pink neon DOC'S outside and I've been coming for years since.  It's a local bar, a blue-collar bar, a hipster bar, a let's stop in for a shot on our way to dinner bar, a let's take shrooms and play shuffleboard all evening bar.  

Please do not walk in and expect to pay with your black AMEX card.  Please do not concern yourself with the odor that rises from the back.  The drunk making noise in front will leave soon, or be kicked out.  If you are looking for good clean fun, please plan your retreat back to Union Street.  

There are good things here for good people, and bad things here for bad people.  And yes, sometimes yes, good things for bad people too.
author: Ryan P.

description:
Things you can learn at 9pm on a Thursday night in a really cool little dive bar in the Mission...

Suede boots and rain don't mix.
A stellar jukebox can pretty much make your night.
Drinks are far cheaper in SF than LA.
Strong drinks are good.
Crazy burgundy flower bathroom walls are kinda the awesome.
Old people on dates are pretty damn cool.
Dogs chillin in bars are rad.
Oh and Shufflepuck is shit tons harder than it looks.

That is all.
author: Stephy S.

description: This is a nice hole in the wall bar...not quite a dive.  The drinks are strong and they have shuffle board which is a plus.  The bartender that served us was super rude...she flat out said you need to leave me a better tip and then would hover around our group looking for money.  Not cool...I won't be back.
author: Lindsey W.

description:
lets face it, the mission is like Mecca for douchebags. I usually stick to my local bar on the weekends to avoid dealing with em. As Oscar Levant once said, "I only drink to make you interesting" 

but

Carey is the best bartender/owner. She's always having small fundraisers to support local groups like the Barbie Deconstruction Party (for a youth writing group & the bay area oil spill clean up). Next time you're in Docs look for decapitated barbies hanging from the walls.

I like going on weeknights or on Sundays...the douche to nice-person ratio is much lower then.
author: chandra g.

description: Cheap Drinks Cheap Drinks Cheap Drinks. And the staff was very nice and the people in the bar were very friendly, plus plus plus.
author: Nicholas A.

description:
Nearly deserted on a Saturday night?  What's going on?  Is it the rain?  The stink-eyed bartender?

But hey, they've got $1 PBR, $3 well drinks, a juke box, and a shuffleboard.  Hell, with those amenities I can fill the place with my own friends!

Sort of.

Ok, I can drink dollar beers with two friends and kick ass at shuffleboard.  Still a recipe for a good night.

SHUFFLE-MASTER M TRIUMPHS AGAIN!!!!
author: Mari C.

description:
As long as it's not too busy, Doc's Clock is a great generic Mission bar.  I think it's great because it doesn't really have much character of its own; it takes on whatever character its patrons bring.  

This is not to say that Doc's Clock lacks characteristics.  For instance, it has dimensions much like a skeleton key of sorts, in that there is a long hallway along which the bar stretches, and ends in a rectangular room at the back; and there is a shuffleboard table in this rectangular room and seating for people to enjoy.  

This is also not to say that Doc's Clock cannot be characterized, because if you asked for such a summary I would tell you that it is a down-home type of place, and that it is generally patronized by reasonable-seeming and reasonable-looking people, and that the pours are strong enough and the prices cheap enough and the help, helpful enough.

But in the way of things, characteristics and characterizations do not character make, and Doc's Clock remains charmingly generic.  And I like it fine that way.
author: Oliver N.

description:
Under my sweater, I was wearing a two-sizes-too-tight plain black tee shirt that says "I'd rather be masturbating" that was supposed to be reserved for when the drunker more assholish Rocco came out.

Unfortunately Doc's Clock was like an African jungle--about 105 degrees with high humidity.  So I had to unleash the skin-on-bologna masturbating shirt a tad too early.

:-(.

Two stars for shuffleboard, and interesting and "cheap" drink specials.  Try the sidecar!

Seriously though, put some fans in the back, and this place wouldn't be half bad.
author: Rocco B.

description:
Stand outside from across the street and take in that sign for a minute. I think this is the single greatest piece of nightlife signage in San Francisco. This part of the Doc's Clock experience is free to boot. One extra star.

Once you're inside, you'll find some other nice touches, like a very long shuffleboard table and Connect Four. Drinks are reasonably priced and I'm pretty sure I saw a bottle of Basil Hayden behind the bar.  That's the good stuff.

But be advised that this bar is kind of like MUNI in that it's long and narrow, and there are all different kinds of people in here from marina types to hipsters to crazy people, and they tend to bunch up in spots so dense that you can't shove through while there's plenty of standing room in other places. And late at night the bar starts to shake violently like MUNI* and there are no overhead bars to hang onto like there are on the bus. If they ever start serving cheap drinks on the 38 this place will have some serious competition.

*No one else I've talked to remembers this part. It might have just been me.
author: matthew r.

description:
This is a cool bar.  It's dive-y and friendly but not really hip.  The space is really narrow and it gets pretty crowded on the weekend so you may find yourself striking up conversations with spirited strangers as you squeeze by.  It's comfortable and I had a fun time.  I'm sure I'd wander over again, if I weren't completely traumatized from my last experience there...

[The following story contains comments which may be considered age-ist.  I advise sensitive readers to press Back now.]

--------Rewind a few months--------

...I've only been to this bar once and I definitely felt a little young.

Perhaps "new" is more accurate.  You see, I was single for the first time since turning 21 (a few years ago) so the whole bars-and-meeting-boys thing was novel and exciting!
[READ: dating maturity of a teenager.]  

I met some nice people there including a couple of interesting men (how exciting!).  One, in particular, was about 55.
[READ: danger danger!]

But he was really interesting (like a family friend or an uncle or upper management).  Two beers later when he asked me for my number, I thought, "Well he seems interesting, maybe it would be fun to chat with him again..."
[READ: light weight.]

--------Fast Forward one day--------

I get a flirty text message from old guy and call my friend for sympathy.
[READ: eeewww]

But what do I get??  Big belly laughs!  And a lesson about "my number" - the first step of some complex romance/sex ritual called "dating".  An alternative ritual "platonic friends" was quite familiar to me, with the exception of a previously unknown symbol: "email address".
[READ: quick learner.]

--------Fast Forward 2 months--------

I'm making late night stop at the corner store to get Electrolyte Replacement Fluid before heading to bed.  I pay for my drink, make a little small talk with the clerk, and head for toward the door, when I hear, "TESSA!"

"Meh?"

"IT'S THE LOVE OF YOUR LIFE!"

"Huh?!?!"
[READ: looks MUCH older under fluorescents, hardly recognizable...]

"Oh wow!  Ha!  You must have had a few too many beers that night!"

"No..."
[READ: horrified!  These other people in the store INCORRECTLY think I did something dirty with old man!]

I run home despite him calling after me.  I close the blinds and hide under the covers.  And I blame it all on Doc's Clock.  They must have really strong beer or something...
author: Tessa M.

description:
Doc's Clock is the kind of place that makes me glad I live within stumbling distance of the Mission.  Cheap drinks, board games which get turned into drinking games at the drop of a hat (my Trivial Pursuit skills get no worse, no better with alcohol.  Win!), a shuffle board, and a good crowd make for a fun night  anytime.  I can walk here, drink my fill, hang out with my friends, then walk/bus home and my total night out is a reasonable $20.

This place is super laid back and the crowd never sways too far towards any one stereotype.  Definitely one of my favorite hang outs.  The bar can be hard to access as the front of the bar is very narrow, but you can still get served because it stretches out pretty far.

And that's all I have to say about that.
author: Zhi Q.

description:
The one star is for the self-serve water dispenser sitting on the bar so you don't have to wave down a bartender who is just going to give you the stink-eye for not ordering something alcoholic. 

Perhaps I went during a particularly unfortunate time (Friday night around 10-ish) but this place was DOUCHEBAG CENTRAL. 

Gross.
author: J N.

description:
... moves too slow most of the time. This place is boring!

But, it's far less obnoxiously crowded and FAR LESS expensive than 12 Galaxies next door, when I'm there for a sold-out show. 

12 Galaxies, which is too dumb to have figured out the no-ins-and-outs rule...

Therefore, by the law of bar relativity, I hereby give Doc's Clock 3 stars instead of 2. 

(And to reap its full benefit, I highly recommend you go there on the weekend, after patronizing another annoying Mission establishment.)
author: Lisa T.

description:
"Hey you guys! Let's go to Doc's Clock! They have shuffleboard!"
"No! Doc's Clock is where you go to make the night die."
"Oh. No it can't be that bad!!!"

"Hey you guys! There's the shuffleboard... oh... well it's being used."
"Does it smell kinda funny to you here? Like wet mice?"
"Well the vodka still tastes like vodka and hey I'm too drunk to care!"
author: Tanya F.

description:
Ended up here since Laszlo was super crowded. The big neon sign caught my attention so had to go check it out. 

For a late Saturday night the bar was not really that crowded. Was able to easily snag 3 chairs to sit. The noise level was not over bearing either so it was easy to have a conversation.

Drinks were good and cheap! 

What was neat about this bar was the shuffleboard and the LOTR pinball machine. My husband, of course, had to play a few games on it. Also they have a selection of board games to play, which I thought was kinda cool, even though we didn't play any. 

Overall nice experience.
author: Jenniffer T.

description:
Perhaps the retro neon marquee sign over the entrance provides inspiration. Perhaps I never have to deal with the Mission hipster crowds because I drop by at 6 and leave soon after 9 on off nights. But what stands out about Doc's are the fine people running the establishment. Although Erica the bartender may have inspired some of the less useful comments below, she inspires many of us to return with some of the finest service I've seen anywhere outside of a down-home diner in a friendly middle-American Lake Wobegone kind of town. Your needs are attended to, your feelings are smoothed, your well-being is accommodated, and your order is served with a smile and a pleasant voice. It's like being served booze by mom, if mom was twentysomething with creative hair and tattoos (and there'd be nothing wrong with that).

The bar didn't provide the cupcakes we ate during the last visit, but I feel like they contributed to promoting the kind of atmosphere where cupcakes are served. With beer.
author: Matt R.

description:
I had to wait twenty minutes to take a piss, while a couple fornicated in the bathroom.

But it's not too dirty, relatively uncrowded on St Patrick's day, and they have shuffle board!

I'll come again.
author: Crystal R.

description: A clean bar with cheap, crappy beer like Hamm's and PBR in cans.  They have a pretty good liquor selection, but apparently can't make cocktails as basic as an old fashioned (at least I was refused when I went recently).  Service was otherwise alright, and a Ms. Pac-Man tabletop is always a plus.
author: Aaron S.

description: Good music, nice bartenders, cool atmosphere and a shuffle board!
author: John M.

description:
Don't forget the Olympia beer.  Looking for a pool table.  No pool table.  Oh, a shuffle board.  Wow.  Looking for a pool table. No pool table.  

Extra stars for $1 PBRs and the decorative theme of plain white walls.
author: greg e.

description:
"too busy to make a bloody mary"???  

I hope this bartender was not too busy to grab tip dollars from her customers!!!
author: binh l.

description:
$1 pabst specials. $2 cans of Olympia (memories of college drift back to me), a list of hot drinks, and shuffle puck. All great things about Doc's Clock.

I like how the mirror has all the specials randomly displayed on homemade signs. It always helps me decide what I want to order. This is a great place to keep on hand, when you want an inexpensive place to chat with your friends.
author: Netty L.

description:
Saturday night:
I go to a show at 12 galaxies...
It is so fucking hot in there that my friend and I go next door for a drink....mmmmm gin!
While my friend is in the restroom...a lovely, cleavage d, blond comments on my hat (my friends hat resting on my head for a moment)
She said:
"Nice hat and I just cock blocked my sister!"
I said: ummmmm...why?
she said: "I'm a lawyer...blah blah, cock block, blah blah, my sister is mad, blah blah"
I said....well...at least you have a nice rack and it won't take long for another cock block opportunity to come along"
It was a great night!
author: Elina D.

description:
If your pants are so tight that they've squeezed the sense right out of you, perhaps you'll like this place. Doc's clock is purgatory for the non-hipster crowd. The juke box is loaded with painfully pretentious and rightfully under-appreciated bands. They have board games in case you get bored, and of course, they have everybody's favorite game shufflepuck. Who invented this asinine game? Is this Canada's fault? Let's take curling, shrink it down, and put it in a bar so drunk morons can agitate everyone else within earshot. No wonder the bartenders here are such assholes.

By the way, don't ask the bartender for change. l needed a quarter, but only had 2 dimes and a nickel. I asked the bartender for change and she looked at me like I had just shot her mom. She then self-righteously informed me that she had no use for 'that', turned her back and walked away. Terrible
author: Dan M.

description:
recently checked this place out..sad that i never made it when i lived in walking distance. 

all around its cool as fuck. weeknight of weekend.
the bartenders were on top of our drinks, chatty and really loved what they were doing.

its the right price in an area where all the douches come out on the weekends hipster and idiot free!

so hipsters and idiots stay away!
author: dawn a.

description: This is a good pit stop on Mission, as there is a little void of bars between 16th and 24th, with a few exceptions. The mixed drinks here surprisingly are also really good.  Cheap beers on tap. I think some for 3? Can't remember for sure... Clean place too....
author: Jim B.

description: They have Root! If you don't know what I'm talking about, go to Doc's Clock immediately and ask for Root with Ginger Ale. You won't be sorry.
author: Allison S.

description: Strong drinks, chill, shuffle board, chill crowd...good local dive bar.
author: Emy s.

description:
Time was, Doc's Clock got more 911 calls than ANY other dive in The City. That was years before I made out with a girl in the john (the jane if the ladies?) or drunkenly fell ass over teakettle at the bar (meant to do that).

I love this place Sunday through Wednesday when it's just a rocking neighborhood bar. But ever since Foreign Cinema opened, at weekends it becomes a waiting room for bridge and tunnel slummers to knock a few back before their foodie frolics.

No jukebox. Good lighting. I really hope after their remodel they retain the glass brick facade. Also, El Rio needs to take a page from Doc's book as regards non-pain in the ass shuffleboard table placement. 

The best times I ever had here, beside the ass over teakettle episode, were the Chimay Cheese promotions. Chimay makes cheese from their beer, like three kinds, and they brought in huge wheels of the stuff, apples and french bread to choke down on the free with $4 Chimays. Woot!
author: Jeremy W.

description:
Free shuffleboard and Happy Hour until 9pm, even on Saturday! 
They also have board games ready for your drunken playing pleasure.
author: Adriane K.

description:
The $2 cans of Olympia are nice.  As is the happy hour that lasts until (I think) 9pm.  My favorite aspect of Doc's Clock, however, are the guaranteed, awk interactions you'll have with dozens of people in regards to the shuffleboard table.  If you want to play shuffleboard, be prepared for a lot of finger pointing, dirty looks, and confusion.

EDIT:  Uggghhh.  If you're the a$$hole that we almost had to fight to play shuffleboard here on Sunday, October 14, 2007, you can seriously buttsecks yourself.  You might be the world's biggest doucheflame.  You know who you are.
author: Sam P.

description:
$1 PBR till 9pm happy hour is so freaking sweet. Add some shuffle puck and your in like Flynn. Great place to get started but the fact that it's apparently a lesbian bar means non-coupled folk will probably have to migrate before the end of the night, hence the one star lost.  When we went last weekend Frank Chu stopped by and was having some very eccentric conversation, as he's known to do. Seriously great place to hit up, but I'd BYOG (Bring your own group/girls)

Best Punk Jukebox in the city. They have Gogol Bordello, seriously that alone is worth a visit, Yelpers trust me when I say. Go inside, order either a PBR or Olympia (oly in a can!), leave your license with her after she checks it, pick up some shufflepucks, head to the jukebox, feed it 5 bucks and play Gogol Bordello's whole album.  A great night will ensue. Also they have more than punk so mix up the tunes after that.
author: Tyler W.

description:
We owned this bar.

We owned the poor suckers who dared challenge us to a game of Connect Four.

We were on top of the world.
author: Beth G.

description:
Maybe it was the joy of the carnaval parade outside that made me overlook the smell of ass that pervades the back of the bar, but I had a great time at Doc's today.  

I don't usually drink bloody Marys, but since I hadn't had lunch, I figured I should get my veggies while getting my drink on.  Two drinks later, I realized that I like them more than I thought I did.  Moving on to margaritas (it was carnaval, after all), I also thought that drink was great.  Normally, I'm a beer drinker, but it was definitely worth passing up on just beer.  Oh wait, I had beer, too.  

No wonder I forgot about the smelly bathrooms.

I will be back to play shuffleboard - a highly-underrated sport.
author: Surf R.

description:
Doc's Clock has a great, retro vibe...kind of feels like stepping back in time. Drinks are cheap and strong...just how I like them! Crowd was great, too. 

Check out their Sunday night specials for really great deals...
author: Brianne K.

description: Ok bar.  Basic hole in the wall neighborhood bar.  Nothing special but good.  One bartender, lots of people and he needs some help!
author: Kevin J.

description:
Too bad we didn't make it to Doc's Clock till the very end of the night on our last night in town- even though it was across the street from our hostel the whole time!! This was the bar we were looking for our whole trip- divey, cozy, seating, board games, and good strong drinks. I don't even know how much money I spent here- that's how strong the drinks were. 

Everyone was really friendly, and there seemed to be some sort of shuffleboard-off in the back while we were there. I also really liked the back-lit bottles of booze lining the lower part of the wall- it made ordering easier for the slightly blurried-eyed with booze patron (namely, me).

Also, when we ordered 2 red-headed slut shots, the bartender screamed (over and over) "where are my sluts?" until we pushed our way back to the bar. Which I found endearing.
author: Tori B.

description:
What?!  You don't open until 6pm?  But 5pm is quittin' time!

I was pretty disappointed to find Doc's Clock's doors chained shut shortly after rounding up a small group of thirsty coworkers for a nice cold (cheap) one.  I had gone on and on about how great DC's happy hour was and how there's a juke box and games and shuffle board!  Cool, right?!  Unfortunately, I didn't even think of the possibility that they'd be closed =(  wah, waah!

Until next time Doc's Clock...
author: Nicole N.

description:
Shufflepuck!!!

And Trumer Pils. And a really nice crowd. I've made really good friends there. 

I'd hate to be the bartender on slow nights because you have to hail a cab to take you from one end of the bar to the other. 

The girl's bathroom is a little unsightly and too well lit. They should dim it down in there. We always look better dimly lit, especially while drinking.

And I wish they'd get the shufflepuck scoreboard working again. That thing is a relic, but awesome. 

But shufflepuck in my 'hood? It will keep me coming back.
author: Rachel F.

description:
Good place to drown your sorrows in cheap pints of PBR (from the tap!).

Can't say I love the music selection played at ear-splitting volumes on some nights, but that and the eclectic Mission-type clientele gives it a good divey vibe that I've come to enjoy.

It's the unpretentious, "come as you are" kind of place where you can nurse your drink without people f'n with you.
author: Bono B.

description:
Doc's Clock isn't my favorite bar by any means, but the thing is, I had one of my favorite nights EVER there...which in part was due to the bartender. This is why I'm giving the place 4 stars. 
Went after band practice to meet a dear friend's sister, who was in town from Chicago. It was low-key(oh, how i love low-keyness), not too busy...we were having a great night. I wanted to get a second drink, but had no money,  the friend had no money, we didn't want to ask her sister for some cash... we were bummed.  The bartender senses our need for another drink, tells us this one's on him...no worries. Just like that...he gives us FREE DRINKS. Do you know how much free drinks mean to me??
And this...dear friends is why I love Doc's Clock.
author: Joanna R.

description: Cheap beer.  Check.  Standing room only.  Check.  Wasted on $10.  Yep.
author: Bibi M.

description:
Doc's can get a bit packed and rowdy on the weekend, but should be your destination spot for Tuesday nights. $1 PBRs (draft, mind you, not cans) starting at 6PM and going until... I have no idea.

The problem is we always get too wasted by the time 8PM rolls around (which is stuble-to-random-Mission-burrito-place-time). Maybe it's $1 PBRs all night long. Grabs some beers, form a couple shuffle board teams, and have a great night.

Oh they also had a special of $3 non-PBR drafts, and $2 shots of some liqour I have never heard of before.

And a confession... I spilled my beer in the sandpit of the shuffle board last night. I am sorry, Doc. I dried it up as best I could with napkins.
author: Trey F.

description:
Good ol' Doc's Clock (more like Doc's Glock am-i-rite?)... laid back and has crazy redneck drinks (Trailerpark punch is girlfriends favorite), also, they have Olympia beer!

They have the worst sound system in the universe, but I really don't care. At least you can have a conversation here unlike *cough* casanova *cough*. 

Also, I'd like to add that the space freakishly elongated, seriously, it feels like I'm drinking in a damn hallway!
author: Jesse S.

description:
1 Dollar PBR
 *1 DOLLAR PBR*
  **1 DOLLAR PBR**

pretty average little bar, but they have pbr for abuck until 9pm every weeknight.  I know, I know, it's just pbr.  Haven't we aged to the point where we desire more sophistication in our libations?   No.  Not for 99 plus 1 cents.

-------------------
- pretty quiet almost every night
- I agree with thadd l. that coming with a big group is more fun because you dominate the scene
- they also have connect 4 and some other wacky bar games
- bartenders are friendly
- never heard the lesbian bar thing, but maybe that's because I'm deliriously lost in my pbr happy place.
- did i mention these are not cans of pbr, but pints?
author: Jonathan K.

description:
Chill, small place. We got the 360 Vodka with cranberry and grapefruit, and the alameda ass (it had sour and ginger ale in it and something else). Both drinks were very strong. Bartender was friendly.

There's a good happy hour on Sunday.

They only accept cash!!!!
author: Angela H.

description:
Parking for my friend's car after endless circling: $15, split four ways.

Pints of Anchor Steam: $4 x 2.

Playing shuffleboard with a bunch of cute boys: priceless.

I like this bar.
author: DD B.

description:
I was there the same night as Beth L, and had an equally good time...  We strolled in with mullets, mod wigs, and tiaras and shut the place down in the wee hours. Pretty awesome that a bar allowed us riffraff to run amok as we did. And our bar tab wasn't too outrageous either.

side note:Dave H. and I positively whipped Beth L. at Connect Four, don't let her tell you different.
author: Tiffany M.

description:
Yet another Mission-bar-turned-psudo-intellectual.

Used to be cool until the Guardian does their annual "Best of the Bay"

I guess it is still cool, depends on the crowd. If I look in and see a few people I know I'll stop. There are better places to go in the Mission.
author: Danny S.

description:
My internal thought process when evaluating Doc's Clock goes something like this:

Do you want to hang out in a place that smells like a big port-a-potty?   "No."

What if the port-a-potty has shuffleboard?  
"Hmm... not really.  If I have to go to the bathroom, though, it would be pretty cool to play shuffleboard while doing it."

There will be a lot seedy characters around, and no, the shuffleboard table is not actually reachable from the toilet. 
"Well, then... negative."

But for the occasional seedy character with great taste, there is Chimay on tap.  
"I'm confused by convergence of all these positives and negatives into one bar.   Please stop."

I really don't know what to make of it, so I'll average everything out to 3 stars.  It honestly does smell like a toilet within a 50 ft radius of this building, though.  Girls, if you plan on getting a kiss, take me somewhere that smells prettier.
author: Joe K.

description:
For a place that's supposedly lowbrow and divey, they have a really impressive selection of bottled delights. Luxardo! Pimm's! American Honey! CYNAR!!! Of course, when it's packed on a weekend night, the bartenders don't have time to mix a schmancy cocktail, but it gives the place a totally unexpected secret touch of class.

Also, they carded me. Yeah, baby!
author: Fawn F.

description:
This place was crowded and noisy, so we decided to go in.  There wasn't much room for us in front, so we decided to make our way to the back of the bar.  After "excuse me" and "pardon me" all the way down the long bar, we realize the back of the bar is hotter, smellier, and the shuffleboard table is taken.  Boo. 

I didn't think this place was anything special, and I'd go again if it were 2pm on a Saturday and I had to play shuffleboard to save my life. :)  Nothin' special.
author: Michelle K.

description:
Something about this place just feels right.  Maybe it is the smell of the shuffleboard powder, the odd diner feel or the really long mens bathroom (that does not seem to have a lock).

Whatever it is.. it's evil.  It makes me buy everyone shots of Jim Beam, and I don't even LIKE Jim Beam!!!

Hang out there for a few hours some night and watch the ebb and flow of the crowd.  You're bound to witness something good.

It can get pretty loud so it's better to go with a group than just a date, unless you're both really into watching people or just making out (in which case Supperclub is where you should be!)

Check it out, and if you see me there buy me a shot of Jim Beam.
author: Kyle R.

description: On a Sunday at 10PM, we had the entire bar to ourselves (there were folks in the back). They let us bring in slices and tacos, though they had set out PB&J, a knife, and Pabst Blue Ribbon toaster on the bar. B&W film on screen; Chimay on tap; cute dog on patrol. 'Nuff said.
author: Faith A.

description:
This place always has a good amount of people in it, the bartenders are attentive and on their game, and speaking of games--
they have board games like Connect Four here to play as you get trashed.
I love this idea, although sometimes it's not easy to get access to a table for gameplay.
author: Light Bulb J.

description:
Cheap PBR ($2). Expensive quality beer on tap ($7 for Duvel). 

Clientele varies from friendly and interesting to boring and drunk. 

Would be a 2-star if not for the awesome shuffleboard!
author: Rene R.

description:
More than its compatriots The Attic & The Latin American Club, this place emphasizes the *dive* in hipster dive;  PBR specials, for instance, are displayed prominently.  Our group instead opted for the Trailer Park Punch (it's got, let's see, OJ, purple stuff, and...alright, Sunny D!)--I think we probably drank 20 of them by the time we left.

This place has two other prominent features that confirm its true hipsterness: the first is the shuffleboard table (sweet!).  The second is the booby-trapped jukebox...seriously, you have to be the Indiana Jones of jukebox heroes to get through it unscathed.  If you get lured into the Ramones, it will probably set off a silent alarm, so choose wisely.  If you want to play it safe, stick with the hipster Green Zone that is Velvet Underground.
author: Wes M.

description:
Great dive bar!  It can be unpleasantly crowded at times.  Also, when I was there last there was a nasty smell coming from the bathroom which had emptied out the rear of the bar.  Great selection of cheap beer, including $2.50 PBRs, $2 Olympia cans and Chimay on tap.  I can't remember the last time I bought cans of beer at a bar, but it was very fitting of the place.

I like that they have board games, but I feel like I'd be judged if I ever played them there.  Shuffleboard seems cool- I never played before, but now I know where I can learn.
author: Jeff A.

description: Have you ever experienced that awkward feeling of being in the Mission and not wanting to dance or stand up and talk to semi-drunk people wearing fedoras and smelling of Parliaments? There aren't many options in this neighborhood for that type of situation--most Mission dives are loud, sweaty, and scene-y. Not so at Doc's Clock. It's one of those refreshing Mission bars with actual seating, a tolerable noise level of interesting music, inexpensive drinks, shuffleboard, and the occasional dog. (Watch your step!) I dig. It's nothing dazzling, but sometimes you need that.
author: Stefanie L.

description:
Going along with Meredith R's review (since she was my date for the evening), all I have to say is, "Shut your whore mouth!" hahahaha I was tempted to jump over the bar and steal this sentiment right off the wall. Another great one was, "I love juggs." LOTS of laughable reading material for your inebriated eyes. 

Loved this establishment. It was the perfect precursor to an eventful evening.
author: Julia N.

description: One day,..Way back when, I stepped off the Muni @ around 20th and Misssion; Everything and everyone looked dangerous and unclean, I spotted Doc's Clock!! Immediately upon entering I knew everthing was going to be allright! They had,..Old Crow in the well!! The rest is History!
author: Kevin B.

description: Had an event here Saturday...These people are AMAZING! The bar has so much going on and I love Puka the former race dog :)
author: Katrina H.

description:
great prices on beer especially during happy hour.
 1great pinball machine and  awesome shuffle board
lots of fun
author: michael d.

description:
Scrabble: check
Connect Four: check
Shuffleboard: check

Add "Chutes and Ladders", "Twister", and Stella on tap and they'll get a five star rating.
author: Jay B.

description:
One word- Shuffleboard.
I come from the middle of America. We actually have these things in a lot of our bars in the mid-land of America. And I must say- it tickles the shit out of me when i can come into a bar and beat the hell out of the Chicago-land, NYC, So Cal trust-fund hipsters at the almighty shuffleboard!
Thank you Doc's Clock. Truly, I am in your debt.
Also, you have good, strong drinks.
I spent my 30th birthday kicking young-en's asses. A birthday well spent, as I am a bitter old lady now.
It also has really weird deco vibe, which I like. 
I can stand the hipsters- as long as they want to play shuffleboard with me...hahaha suckas!!
author: shannon t.

description: It's a good vibe, the hand shuffle board is lots of fun, but it ALWAYS smells like urine. And not just by the bathroom, unfortunately -- one star off for that.  But despite this hardship, we've had many a good time here
author: Vanessa H.

description: So I've been to Doc's Clock before. It's a cool dive, but what I'm TOTALLY digging is "Doc's Cold Remedies" which is a list of hot temp alcoholic drinks. I had their apple cider, which was like an adult holiday drink--totally boozy and delicious. Buuuut their MAKER'S MARK hot chocolate (and I emphasize Makers Mark because that's my favorite.liquor.evarrr) was SOOO good. It was like the two best things in the world--chocolate and Maker's Mark--came together to make LIQUID AWESOMENESS. Cold weather or cold-flu, I would drink any of these creations any day. *love*
author: Alex H.

description:
Cheap beer and connect four? 

Brilliance.
author: Krissy M.

description:
Get your cheap drinks here!  Quite a few beers on tap and great mixed drinks for no more than $4.  Also stumbling distance to a bomb taqueria.  

Shuffle board: +1
Board Games (I swear, next time I'll be coherent enough to play): +1
Cheap drinks: +1
Dive bar atmosphere: +1
Dive bar bathroom: -1
author: Kathleen B.

description: A Great Bar!  What a Mission bar should be - good folks, good booze, great atmosphere, and good prices.  What its not - foofy drinks, trendy, or Marina d-bags looking to "slum it" in the Mission.  This place kicks ass, takes names, and has got shuffleboard to top it off!  Love this place!
author: Mo P.

description:
When I'm out with Friends drinking I like to have some kind game or contest. I think it's hilarious to watch people get more and more competitive the drunker they get. This place has a 30' long shuffleboard table and several classic games you can play like trivial pursuit, connect 4, etc in the back. 

Tip: Order a Phil Collins and see what you get. It's the house specialty.
author: Nate S.

description:
Very standard bar.  Not that it is bad.  Just so typical.  I mean, ok, you are in the mission and you have a dirty bar with mis-matched tables/chairs/stools and some PBR in a can. Wow.  No great tunes.  No pool table and only an 'ok' shuffle board.  In this area you have to do something different.

the best time to go here is with 10+ people because you will own the bar, it is dead just about every night.
author: Thadd L.

description:
Sometimes it's stinky, like a half-heartedly sanitized dive bar bathroom is, but it's totally worth it for the free shuffleboard and pretty cheap drinks.  I don't know what that says about me.

Updated 9/26/06: Ok, seriously? I have decided this is my favorite bar in the city.  Judge me as you will. Ditto the above reasons, plus add that the crowd is generally a great bunch.
author: Shannon V.

description:
Tuesday night this place smelled like raw sewage that had been in the sun for a month, I couldn't even go past the front door. Whoa...
Update:
The staff are really friendly, the place is much sweeter smelling since last time. Good selection of beer on tap.
author: Colleen B.

description: Good place to chill at after some burritos down the street.
author: Jorge H.

description:
The sign out front said PBR 2 dollars.  I ordered one, she said 3 dollars.

I was pretty cranky after that but I tried to shrug it off and hang out with some Meet Uper's and Yelpers and all in all, it was a good time.

Then they ran out of PBR and a few of us got a little upset, but you know as adults, we tried to not make too much of a scene.

They have a bunch of board games there which I didn't get to play, but if I go back I probably will.  I am a rather mean scrabble player.

I recently had to deal with some cat pee drama and it has quite a unique smell.  I don't know why but Doc's has the same odor in it.  

But since when are Dive Bars supposed to smell good?
author: Adam C.

description:
I like pink lights.  I like it when the people I came with are the only people in the bar.  I like a bar with a good selection of board games.  I like that I don't have to refill my own Singapore Sling while playing Scrabble.  I like that I didn't even see shuffleboard and was still a happy camper.

Hence, I like Doc's clock.  I made myself thirsty, let's go get a drink.
author: Beth V.

description:
All I can say about Doc's Clock is this: I like a bar that is just a bar.  This place is narrow, its mildly grimy and poorly lit (in other words perfect); its rarely too packed to get a drink and service is generally pretty good.

*personal note* I'd give it a sixth star if I could because they have Oly in a can.  I'm new to the city, but so far this is my favorite bar in SF.
author: Jonathan B.

description:
Another great MIssion bar. We stopped by there after the Prince concert and met up with some friends who had been drinking all night; we had a couple hour booze break at the concert so there was some catching up to do, and boy was the bartender helpful in that endeavor: Shots and Stellas--yummy. Last ones to leave, and I was so buzzed I invited our wasted friends over to our house. One broken glass and a red cosmo stain on the wool rug later, I kicked them out 3:30. 

Hey it isn't fancy, but the people are real and drinks are strong.
author: Deborah S.

description: Cheap drinks + chill crowd + quick service, makes me a happy chica!  I'm always a fan of kickback dive bars, that have cool people and enough room for me to stand or sit.
author: Rebecca D.

description:
I have this really funny story involving a rainy night  and an old dude of mine and this bar. I will not tell this story.

Docs is aight, I mostly just come here to use the bathroom if its too long of a long at 12 galaxies(SHHH DONT TELL NOBODY).


ahhhh the story of the rainy night, ill tell you when you are older
author: Lauren V.

description:
I'm not sure why a bar would smell like cat pee, but the fact that that didn't take away from the great vibe this place gives off says something.

Art deco meets retro meets swinger meets punk atmosphere. 

The drinks are cheap and good. The people there, especially the bartenders are incredibly friendly and the music fit the mood of the place...eclectic yet almost not, but definitely fitting in with the decor.

Speaking of the decor...I loved it ranging form the bottles along the back to the ironic 70s beer ads. Everything looks like it belong in a non-contrived way.

When it's empty, it's a great place to bring someone to talk...when it's full it's an even better place to absorb the atmosphere and people watch. 

The only downside is that they don't take credit cards. To make up for it they do have an ATM in the back.

Go!
author: Paul W.

description:
This place does not have "hipness" or even "chicness," but it is really cool. It is this huge bar in the Mission, with tons of interesting people and activities.

I went with some friends after dinner and we had a great time. We played connect four, some other game, and shuffleboard. Shuffleboard was the best. The truth is, the bar is big, so they can fit a cool game like shuffleboard inside.

The drinks were cheap. Eight dollars for a beer and a well. Not super cheap, like happy hour cheap, but still a great place for the now "trendy" mission district.

They even sell Halloween-size candy in a little machine for $0.25, which I liked. I love chocolate and I love machines from the 80's, which this was. If it steals your money, the bartender will give you more quarters.

It's a great place, a little hidden, a little bit of a dive, but super cool. You should go with your really cool friends and you will have a great time. It gets a five because it's my new favorite "local" bar.
author: Christopher W.

description:
Shuffleboard. Board games. Frogger (only if it worked, the code still made a pretty awesome tabletop). Cheap drinks. All in all a winning combination.

Just turn down the lights.
author: Matt L.

description:
Typically a bar doesn't sell PBR if they sell OLYMPIA.  Well this shitty dive bar does and for that it will be forever in my heart!

Oh by the way, I'll kill anybody in shuffleboard under any rules!
author: Justin C.

description: It's a fun laid back bar with a good bartending  team. Affordable prices and fun holiday drink menu. Peppermint Schnapps & hot coco? YES!!! Just a nice chill place to end the night!
author: Marissa P.

description: Thursday night HH will knock you out. Maybe it's every night hh? Idk, but I had fun. Pretty decent selection on the Juke Box! And I LOVVVEEE playing shuffleboard...not too many well sanded ones in this city..note: it curves to the right!
author: Krystha B.

description:
Walking down Mission Street I was amazed by the activity in the street. The Mission is always busy on Friday nights but I've never seen it quite like this! Crowds of people of all ages cruised up and down the sidewalks. Parents escorted their costumed kids from storefront to storefront trick r' treating, which a motley flow of folks dressed in work attire or their Halloween best zipped up the 24th Street BART station's escalators on their way home or ready to hit some Halloween festivities. The mood on the street was both spooky and joyous on this windy autumn night.

The bar de jour turned out to be Doc's Clock and I knew right away that it was a good find. I was greeted at Doc's Clock by two women dressed in black handing out candy to the continuous stream of kids. With knickknacks and tchotkies adorning the walls, Doc's had a distinct trailer park feel with an extra layer of Halloween décor. Settling into my seat I selected a Big Daddy as my beverage of choice.

For more check out http://www.missiononmission.com/2008/11/docs-clock-2575-mission-street.html
author: Gadiel M.

description:
After a long day, I like to have a drink or two (maybe even more than that) to unwind and relax. Doc's Clock has that calm and friendly vibe to it which I like. It doesn't get overly packed and the crowd ranges from young adults to the middle aged. Every time I've gone, everyone is extremely friendly.. including the bartenders. They are always cheerful and attentive. Their sort of like specialty drink is the trailer park punch.. it's a must try. It's only $4 bucks and it's super delicious. 

The first thing I remember noticing about this bar was the four foot tall unicorn head bottle of booze... with the sign referring to it as "unicorn pee." Where can you see that at?? It's awesome. Not to mention the shuffle board and the old school video arcade games. This is definitely by far the best dive bar I've been to. 

Last thing, if you get the munchies for some bomb-ass mexican food, El Farolito is literally two blocks down. Booze + Burritos = A good time. :)
author: Rosa L.

description: I don't even really drink but I loved this bar! Why? Plenty of places to sit, a dog named Henry, and board games!!
author: Conny W.

description: Went on a slow night but the mixed group of folks were cool and the bartender was happy to serve up anything I had in mind. I'll be going back when it's rowdy.
author: Wilfred C.

description: Went to Doc's clock several times and had a great time. First time the morning after was a little painful but that is what follows a fun night. Cheap drinks, and definitely a place with character.  Staff is friendly and easy to become a regular and enjoy a beer or 10 after a hard day of work. They allow food from outside and host Thai. They also used to host tapas on sunday nights
author: Candido B.

description:
Doc's Clock...what a San Francisco gem.

Love a bar where there are other things to do than drink beer and shout at your friends trying to have a conversation.   Great date place...you can get some one-on-one time thinly disguised as a "game" called "shuffleboard".   And, for those with a competitive tendency, added bonus.

Definitely a hipster bar, and definitely a bar with "shuffleboard regulars", so be careful who you challenge to a game; I've seen some pretty incredible spin moves here.

Minuses:
* very limited selection of beers on tap
* on Fridays and Saturdays it gets really crowded and hard to get on the table (but its fun to just watch sometimes and heckle)

Go early on a worknight with a few friends and your likely to hold table until around 9:30-10pm when the regulars roll in (you'll know them by their swagger and the PBR or Tecate (and the occasional Chimay) in hand)
author: aekta s.

description:
Anywhere with PBR gets an automatic 3 star.

A nice mixed crowd, actually really fun mixed crowd.

Felt the place had that really pleasant not trying to be anything more than it is charm.  

Attentive bartenders who won't coddle you, but who cares. 

Worth a visit.
author: E C.

description: Very fun local bar in the Mission! Lisa is an AMAZING bartender she is fun, funny, fast and a joy to be around she is the reason to go to Docs! I LOVE LISA! Go see her she will make you smile.
author: Joe S.

description: Doc's Clock is the best no nonsense bar in the Mission. I always meet the nicest people/ prices are good/ emphasis on local brews/ games/ cute pictures up in the bathroom...I love this place.
author: L T.

description: The door dick is a dick.  At least this time, I remembered why I don't come here before I got in.  I wanna meet him in a dark alley.
author: Emilio O.

description: I've only been here on Sundays for Three Papaya's Brunch. I enjoy the staff very much and the food is amazing if you aren't a veggie. They do have a really amazing green papaya salad for veggies though.I take all my friends/couchsurfers here when they visit the city.  I love the atmosphere and staff. Also lots of games to play with your friends or strangers in the bar.
author: Jessica R.

description: I know bartenders have a tendency to come and go, but I hope the ones I had are there to stay, they were awesome. Also, shuffleboard and cheap beer rocks my socks, I will be back in due time.
author: Matt F.

description: With Jason K as my best friend and stylist, I tend to leave the house looking like a two bit hooker when we hit the town. I can honestly say that if you're going to spend an hour taping your sluttiest dress to your chest and applying flawless makeup, Doc's Clock is not the way to go. I never felt like my looks and my legs were more wasted than during the two hours I spent here. I don't know much about this place (I was three sheets to the wind when we arrived) but I do know this: it is too narrow and too crowded to navigate in 5" stilettos, the bathroom lines are too long to comfortably wait in in 5" stilettos, the crowd isn't attractive, and the drinks aren't strong enough for me. Still, it didn't suck and I've spent a lot more time in much worse places. Plus, it's a decent choice if you happen to be in the Mission. Just wear sensible shoes.
author: Autumn K.

description: I love Doc's Clock! And no one loves it as much as I do. I have had some amazing good times here, but my favorite is one night when I was super sick and dragged myself in, wanting to say goodbye to a close friend who was leaving for the east coast the next day, and when the bartender asked me how I was, I was honest and said fucking miserable. He immediately made me a hot toddy in a pint glass, without even saying anything. He promised it would make me feel better. And it did! It was a beautiful, pure moment that only could've been possible under the pink lights of Doc's Clock.
author: Maria D.

description: Yeay for their $2 beer specials.  All day everyday.  The beer pong table is interesting to watch as well; however I wouldn't dare play on it for fear of contracting any hipster transmitted diseases.
author: Ivy R.

description: Definitely my kind of bar. Very mellow on all counts, not too loud, good drinks, not too crowded and not too hipster pretentious, either. It's this nice narrow bar and you never have to fight for a drink. Shuffleboard is kind of a cool novelty to have in a bar, although you have to wait forever to even get a spot on the table. Just an all around nice place, I can't believe I don't go here more often...
author: Michael E.

description: Dog friendly to the point of donating its happy hour proceeds to on Friday Wonderdog rescue. Speaking of happy hour - a beer and vodka tonic for $6?! YES.
author: Mirabella Y.

description:
doc's clock rocks!  

their amazing happy hour hours (6-9p) and shuffle board knock my socks off.
author: jane d.

description: A true Mission hipster bar, it's good for drowning some sorrows. They have a great shuffle board table in back as well.
author: Nish N.

description:
